thread.title: David Wright now has 2nd quest to conquer in California
thread.title_full: David Wright now has 2nd quest to conquer in California | New York Post

author: Mike Puma
title: David Wright now has 2nd quest to conquer in California
text:
For David Wright, it can be considered a triumphant return.
When the Mets captain arrives in Los Angeles this week to prepare for Game 1 of the NLDS against the Dodgers on Friday, it will mark a return to the vicinity in which he spent some of his darkest moments this summer and forged a hope for the future.
Diagnosed in May with spinal stenosis, Wright spent nearly two months rehabbing his lower back in Southern California, checking in each Monday with renown orthopedist Robert Watkins at his offices in Marina Del Rey, not 20 miles from Dodger Stadium, for a weekly evaluation.
With the Mets remaining in NL East-title contention during his absence, the goal was obvious.
“I think it was nice, when you are going through that therapy, going through that treatment, thinking about the endgame, thinking about coming back and hopefully helping this team get to the postseason,” said Wright, who returned to the Mets on Aug. 24 and hit .277 with four homers and 13 RBIs over the final six weeks to help the Mets win their first division title since 2006.
Included was a home run in the Mets’ NL East clincher in Cincinnati on Sept. 26.
As much as the Mets appreciated Wright’s numbers, just getting him back to a lineup that added Yoenis Cespedes at the trade deadline and returned Travis d’Arnaud from a long stay on the disabled list was significant.
“The way he came back, he gave us an on-field lift as well as more of a psychological lift,” general manager Sandy Alderson said. “For him to come back and have the immediate impact he did, the home run in his first at-bat [in Philadelphia] was a big morale boost for the team.”
Manager Terry Collins was prudent in his usage of Wright down the stretch. The third baseman did not play more than six straight games without a day off and continues a specialized pregame workout routine to strengthen the muscles in his back.
To help bridge the gap while Wright was sidelined, Alderson acquired Juan Uribe and Kelly Johnson in a trade with the Braves on July 24 and both were important contributors in the second half.
Wright called it “bittersweet” to reach the playoffs in a season in which he was limited to 38 games.
“Obviously I would have liked to have been here and played more games,” Wright said. “But you could either moan and whine about it and feel sorry for yourself, or go out there and do what you can do to get back as quickly as possible and I felt that was the option that we had and it feels good to celebrate.”
Only fittingly, it was Wright who took the microphone and thanked the fans on Sunday after the Mets completed the regular season with a 1-0 victory over the Nationals at Citi Field.
“I wish we could have gotten them home-field advantage — that didn’t work out how we had planned,” Wright said. “But I think that very early on this year, I think that they understood that we had something special and the way they have turned out, the way they have supported us, I wish we could have clinched at home, to celebrate with them, but I think a lot of us felt it was necessary to salute the fans for coming out the way they did to making this such a memorable season.”
